questions.text: Which of the following provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)?
questions.solution:
The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG). The most important criterion in conduit selection is graft patency. The conduit with the highest patency rate is the left internal mammary artery or internal thoracic artery.

Left internal mammary artery > Radial artery > long saphenous vein represents the correct order of graft patency in a patient undergoing a CABG procedure.

Venous grafts:

  • The long saphenous vein is the most common vein used as a conduit as it is straightforward to harvest, provides good length, and is easy to handle.
  • The ten-year patency rate for long saphenous vein grafts is reported to be 50–60 percent.

Arterial grafts:

  • The Left internal mammary artery (LIMA) or internal thoracic artery has become the conduit of choice for the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. The radial artery can be used as a second or alternative arterial bypass graft. Other arterial bypass grafts include the gastroepiploic artery and the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Long patency rates of >98 percent have been reported.

questions.text: A patient with radial head fracture presents with an inability to extend the metacarpophalangeal joint. On examination, wrist extension is normal with no sensory impairment. Which of the following nerves is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, there is a likely injury to the posterior interosseous nerve.

It is prone to be injured in radial head fractures as the nerve winds around the radial neck to go into the posterior compartment of the forearm. There is no cutaneous sensory loss in lesions confined to the posterior interosseous nerve.

The radial nerve divides into 2 branches, namely superficial (sensory) and deep (motor) branches at the cubital fossa. 

Deep radial nerve after supplying extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) and supinator, continues as posterior interosseous nerve (PIN). From the posterior compartment, the supinator muscle wraps around the upper 1/3rd of the radius to reach the anterior compartment. 

PIN arches and winds around the radial neck along with the supinator muscle, into the posterior compartment of the forearm. Hence, it is in close relation with the radial head and neck, and the supinator arch or arcade of Froese. 

There is no cutaneous innervation by the posterior interosseous nerve.

questions.text:
Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery?
  1. Superior gluteal artery
  2. Inferior gluteal artery
  3. Superior vesical artery
  4. Middle rectal artery
  5. Inferior vesical artery
  6. Vaginal artery
questions.solution:
The branches from the anterior division include 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. 

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  1. Obturator artery
  2. Superior vesical artery
  3. Inferior vesical artery 
  4. Inferior gluteal artery
  5. Middle rectal artery
  6. Vaginal artery (in females)
  7. Uterine artery (in females)
  8. Internal pudendal artery

Branches of the posterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries
  • Superior gluteal artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the appendicular artery?

choices.text: Supplies the appendix and terminal ileum
Terminal segment of the artery is susceptible to thrombosis
It arises directly from the superior mesenteric artery
Artery of Seshachalam, an accessory appendicular artery, arises from the anterior cecal artery

questions.solution:
The terminal part of the appendicular artery lies on the wall of the appendix and may become thrombosed in appendicitis, resulting in distal gangrene or necrosis.

The appendicular artery provides blood supply only to the appendix (Option A); it is an end artery and is a branch of the ileocolic artery.

The appendicular artery usually arises directly from the ileocolic artery (Option C) and descends posterior to the terminal ileum to enter the mesoappendix, a short distance from the base of the appendix. Here, it gives off a recurrent branch, which anastomoses at the base of the appendix with a branch of the posterior cecal artery.

Less commonly, the appendicular artery may arise from the posterior cecal artery or an ileal artery. An accessory appendicular artery called the artery of Seshachalam arising from the posterior cecal artery may be present. (Option D)

questions.text: During a parotidectomy, oozing is noted from the vein running within the substance of the gland. The concerned vein is formed by the joining of which of the following?

choices.text: Superficial temporal vein and Maxillary vein
Transverse facial vein and Superficial temporal vein
Facial vein and Posterior auricular vein

questions.solution:
The vein that runs through the substance of the parotid gland is the retromandibular vein. It is formed by the union of the superficial temporal vein and the maxillary vein.

It can be remembered that the termination of the external carotid artery and the formation of the retromandibular vein, have the same named branches and tributaries, respectively.

The retromandibular vein is joined by the transverse facial vein within the gland. The retromandibular vein then divides into the anterior and posterior divisions at the lower pole of the parotid. The anterior division joins the facial vein and the posterior division joins the posterior auricular vein.

Other important structures within the substance of the parotid gland are:

The External carotid artery, which divides into the maxillary artery and superficial temporal artery as its terminal branches.

The extracranial Facial Nerve, which divides as follows:

  • Temporofacial branch, which gives off the following branches:
    • Temporal
    • Zygomatic
  • Cervicofacial branch, which gives off the following branches:
    • Buccal, further dividing into the upper buccal and lower buccal
    • Marginal Mandibular
    • Cervical

questions.text: A resident was inserting a central venous line through the femoral vein. However, he accidentally advanced the needle causing injury to the structure lying immediately medial to the femoral vein, lying within the femoral sheath. Which of the following structures is injured?
questions.solution:
The lymphatic vessels lie medial to the femoral vein and are likely to be injured in this case.

Femoral sheath is the funnel-shaped prolongation of the fascia which contains femoral vessels. Anteriorly it is made of transversalis fascia and posteriorly it is made of fascia iliaca.

It is divided into three compartments:

  • The lateral compartment contains the femoral artery
  • The intermediate compartment contains the femoral vein
  • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains lymphatic vessels, areolar tissue, and lymph node of Cloquet.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presented with sudden painless loss of vision and the following finding on fundoscopy. The artery involved is a direct branch of the vessel that travels through which of the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of sudden painless loss of vision with a cherry red spot noted on fundoscopy is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). The central retinal artery is a direct branch of the ophthalmic artery which passes through the optic canal.

The structures passing through the optic canal are the optic nerve and the ophthalmic artery.

The major structures passing through the superior orbital fissure (Option A) are:

  • Oculomotor, Trochlear and Abducens Nerves (CN III, IV, VI)
  • Lacrimal, Frontal and Nasociliary branches of the ophthalmic division of the Trigeminal Nerve (CN V1)
  • Superior and Inferior Ophthalmic Veins

The structures passing through the inferior orbital fissure (Option B) are:

  • Infraorbital and Zygomatic branches of the maxillary division of the Trigeminal Nerve (CN V2)

The structures passing through the cavernous sinus (Option C) are:

  • Internal Carotid Artery
  • Abducens Nerve

The structures in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus are:

  • Oculomotor, Trochlear and Ophthalmic Division of the Trigeminal Nerves (CN III, IV, V1)

questions.text: In a patient, following venous cut down for access to the great saphenous vein, sensations over the medial side of the leg was lost. Which of the following nerves is involved in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Loss of sensation of the medial side of the leg following venous cut down for access to the great saphenous vein denotes injury to the saphenous nerve which is a branch of the posterior division of femoral nerve.

Saphenous nerve:

  • It is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body.
  • It arises from the posterior division of the femoral nerve. In the femoral triangle, it lies lateral to the femoral artery.
  • It then enters the adductor canal where it crosses anterior to the femoral artery to lie medial to it. It leaves the adductor canal by piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius and supplies the skin over patella.
  • It then descends along the medial border of tibia along with long saphenous vein and supplies the skin on the medial side of knee leg and foot as far as up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is related to the area marked A in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
The area marked A is where the azygos vein arches over the hilum of the right lung.

The diagram shown is of the right lung, identified by the presence of hyparterial and eparterial bronchus at the hilum.

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: An intern was asked to give an intravenous injection to a vein in the cubital fossa. All of the following are true about the cubital fossa except:

choices.text: Musculocutaneous nerve is one of the contents
Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally
Median cubital vein forms the roof

questions.solution:
The musculocutaneous nerve is not a content of the cubital fossa.

The cubital fossa is a triangular depression present in the anterior side of the elbow joint. The boundaries of the cubital fossa include:

  • Medially: Lateral border of the pronator teres
  • Laterally: Medial border of the brachioradialis (option A)
  • Base: Proximally by an imaginary line joining the epicondyles of the humerus
  • Apex (pointed downward): Joining of the lateral and medial boundaries.
  • Roof: Skin, superficial fascia containing median cubital vein (option D) joining the cephalic and basilic veins, lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, medial cutaneous nerve of the forearm, bicipital aponeurosis, and deep fascia.
  • Floor: Brachialis and supinator muscles.

The contents of the brachial fossa are (from medial to lateral side):

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery, terminating into radial and ulnar arteries
  • Biceps brachii tendon with the bicipital aponeurosis
  • Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally (option C) in the groove between the brachialis and brachioradialis

Clinical significance:

  • The median cubital vein is the most commonly preferred vein of choice for intravenous injections. 
  • Auscultation of the brachial artery in front of the elbow helps in measuring the blood pressure.

questions.text: An angiography study was done for a patient who presented with chronic dysphagia. The following vascular anomaly of the aortic arch was found to be the cause. Identify the anomaly.
questions.solution:
The vascular anomaly that is causing the dysphagia in this patient is an aberrant right subclavian artery. This condition is known as dysphagia lusoria.

Dysphagia lusoria is dysphagia produced due to compression of the esophagus by a developmental vascular anomaly, often an aberrant right subclavian artery. It arises directly from the aortic arch.

It can be diagnosed by CT angiography. Treatment is surgical repair either by reconstruction or ligation of the aberrant right subclavian artery.

The CT image below shows the presence of an aberrant right subclavian artery:


The CECT below shows the origin of the aberrant right subclavian artery (red arrow) causing extrinsic compression of the esophagus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most medial structure passing through the canals in the flexor retinaculum of the foot?
questions.solution:
Tibialis posterior tendon is the most medial structure passing through the canals in the flexor retinaculum of the foot.

The flexor retinaculum of the foot converts grooves on the tibia and calcaneus into canals for the tendons. The structures passing through canals formed by flexor retinaculum are as follows: (Starting from the medial side- mnemonic Tom, Dick And Very Nervous Harry)

T: tibialis posterior tendon
D: flexor digitorum longus
A: artery (posterior tibial)
V: vein (posterior tibial)
N: nerve (tibial)
H: flexor hallucis longus tendon

questions.text: Artery passing through the structure marked in the diagram below is a branch of?
questions.solution:
The image shown is the ligament of head of the femur and the artery passing through it is a branch of obturator artery.

The blood supply of the femoral head is derived from an arterial ring (Trochanteric anastomosis) around the neck of femur constituted by:

  • Medial circumflex femoral arteries 
  • Lateral circumflex femoral arteries
  • Superior and inferior gluteal vessels (minor contributions)

questions.text: During laparoscopic hernia surgery in a male patient, a nerve located within the triangle of doom is injured. This nerve provides sensory innervation to which of the following regions?

choices.text: Anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament

questions.solution:
The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve is a content of the triangle of doom and can be injured in laparoscopic hernia surgery. The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve supplies sensation to the skin of the scrotum.

The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve provides nerve supply to:

  • Motor innervation to the cremaster muscle in males
  • Sensory innervation to:
    • The skin of the scrotum in males
    • Mons pubis and labia majora in females

The boundaries of the triangle of doom are:

  • Medially- ductus deferens
  • Laterally- gonadal vessels in the spermatic cord
  • Posteroinferiorly- peritoneal reflection
  • Apex- deep inguinal ring

The important contents of the triangle of doom include:

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerve

Other important surgical landmarks in this region are the triangle of pain and the crown of death.

The figure below shows the triangle of doom with its boundaries and contents-

Other options:

Option A: The suprapubic area is supplied by the iliohypogastric nerve and it can be injured following appendicectomy. It can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in a direct inguinal hernia.

Option B: The anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament is supplied by the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve.

Option D: The root of the penis is supplied by the ilioinguinal nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following Couinaud segments of the liver drains directly into the inferior vena cava?
questions.solution:
Segment 1 (Caudate lobe) drains directly into the Inferior vena cava(IVC).

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage.

The left lobe is composed of the left lateral segment (Couinaud’s segments II and III) and the left medial segment (segment IV). The right lobe is composed of segments V, VI, VII, and VIII, with segments V and VIII making up the right anterior lobe and segments VI and VII making up the right posterior lobe.

Segment I corresponds to the caudate lobe of the liver and segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe of the liver. Segment IV is divided into segments IVa and IVb.

All the Couinaud segments are supplied by the portal vein and hepatic artery for the arterial supply. Venous drainage of Couinaud segments II to VIII drained into right and left hepatic veins except for segment I (Caudate lobe) which drains directly into the Inferior vena cava. All segments drained lymph into respective right and left hepatic ducts.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the diagram given below:
questions.solution:
The above image shows spinal accessory nerve. Spinal accessory nerve enters the posterior triangle passing deep to the sternocleidomastoid muscle and runs in an oblique direction within the triangle to supply Trapezius.

Phrenic nerve is seen related to the anterior surface of Scalenus anterior. 

Greater auricular nerve (C2,3) Lesser occipital nerve (C2) and supraclavicular nerve (C3,4) emerge from the posterior border of sternocleidomastoid muscle.

Lesser occipital nerve runs upwards along the posterior border of sternocleidomastoid muscle, greater auricular nerve ascends across the muscle and supraclavicular nerve descends and supplies skin over the clavicle).

questions.text: A male patient was posted for abscess drainage from the ischioanal fossa. While draining the abscess, the surgeon injures the nerve present in Alcock's canal. Which nerve is injured in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
The nerve that passes through Alcock's canal and is injured in the given scenario is the pudendal nerve.

Alcock's canal or pudendal canal is an enclosed fascia along the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa. Its contents include:

  • Internal pudendal artery
  • Internal pudendal vein
  • Pudendal nerve

The pudendal nerve originates from the ventral rami of S2, S3, and S4 of the sacral plexus. It exits out of the pelvis by passing through the greater sciatic foramen. It then enters the perineum below the pelvic floor. 

In the pudendal canal, the pudendal nerve gives off the inferior rectal nerve, perineal nerve, and dorsal nerve of the penis or clitoris.

In females, the pudendal nerve supplies sensory branches to the lower of the vagina. Therefore, in vaginal surgeries, anesthesia can be infiltrated near the ischial spine by a needle passed through the vaginal wall and then guided by a finger.

The image given below shows the contents and boundaries of the ischioanal fossa.


Other options:

Option A: Obturator nerve is formed by ventral divisions of L2, L3, and L4 of the lumbar plexus. It descends within the psoas major and then on the lateral wall of the pelvis before entering the obturator foramen to enter the thigh. It has no branches in the abdomen or pelvis.

Option B: Genitofemoral nerve is formed by the ventral rami of L1, and L2 of the lumbar plexus. It pierces the psoas major and emerges out on the anterior surface. It descends and crosses obliquely behind the ureter and divides into genital and femoral branches.

Option D: Accessory obturator nerve is formed by the L2 and L3 of the lumbar plexus. It runs on the posterior surface of the superior pubic ramus. It supplies the pectineus and hip joint.

questions.text: The relationship of the components of the neurovascular bundle from below upwards in intercostal space is _______
questions.solution:
The arrangement of the components of the neurovascular bundle in the intercostal space from below upwards is nerve-artery-vein. 

The arrangement can be remembered from above downwards with the mnemonic VAN: vein-artery-nerve.

questions.text: An elderly man with atherosclerosis presented with abdominal pain and blood-stained stools.  CECT abdomen is suggestive of ischemic colitis at the splenic flexure involving the marginal artery of Drummond. What are the arteries contributing to the formation of this structure?

choices.text: Right colic and left colic arteries
Left colic and middle colic arteries

questions.solution:
The middle and left colic arteries contribute to the formation of the marginal artery of Drummond at the splenic flexure. The splenic flexure (Griffith's point) is a watershed area of the colon which is more prone to ischemia. 

The anastomotic vessel that runs in the mesentery along the inner margin of the colon is called the marginal artery of Drummond. From this artery, numerous small branches are given to the large bowel. It is formed by:

  • Branches of superior mesenteric artery - middle colic, right colic, and ileocolic arteries
  • Branches of inferior mesenteric artery - left colic, sigmoid, and superior rectal arteries

When ischemia occurs at Griffith's point, the blood supply in this region is augmented by another arterial loop called the inner arterial arc (of Riolan). This arc connects the main trunk of the middle colic artery with the ascending branch of the left colic artery.

Note: Sudeck's point is another watershed area present at the rectosigmoid junction. The sigmoid artery anastomoses with the superior rectal artery at this site.

questions.text: In a cadaveric dissection, the openings of the diaphragm were observed. Through which of the following openings does the vagus nerve pass?
questions.solution:
The anterior and posterior trunks of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) pass through the esophageal hiatus (4) of the diaphragm. 

Other structures:

  • 1 - Medial arcuate ligament 
  • 2 - Aortic opening 
  • 3 - Vena caval opening


The structures that pass throught the esophageal hiatus apart from the esophagus are the anterior and posterior vagal trunks, gastric nerves, oesophageal branches of the left gastric vessels and lymphatic vessels.

Other options: 

Option A: The right and left sympathetic chains pass behind the medial arcuate ligament.

Option B: Aortic hiatus allows the passage of the aorta, thoracic duct, lymphatic trunks rom lower posterior thoracic wall and occasionally azygos and hemiazygos veins. 

Option D: Vena caval opening transmits the inferior vena cava but not the vagus nerve.

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

Major openings through the diaphragm

Level of opening

T8

T10

T12

Located in

In the central tendon

In the muscular part

In crus of the diaphragm

Structures passing through

 

Inferior Vena cava

Right phrenic nerve 

Oesophagus

Vagus nerve- right and left

Aorta

Thoracic duct

Azygous vein

Hemiazygous vein

 

Minor openings through the diaphragm

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery
  • Medial arcuate ligament - Sympathetic chain
  • Lateral arcuate ligament - Subcostal nerves and vessels

 

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.
